Lee Smolin presents a compelling case for the institutional, sociological, and historical factors that have caused physics to fail to answer the basic questions left open by the Standard Model over the past 30 years.The book opens with an outline of the open problems left in the wake of the Standard Model and is notable for demanding that a theory be both accurate in the sense that it makes testable predictions that hold under scrutiny AND that the theory make sense in providing a framework on reality rather than being strictly descriptive. This puts him in contrast to thinkers who don't demand intelligibility only descriptive accuracy and I tend to agree with this requirement.Smolin then wages two wars: one against string theory as a way of uniting quantum mechanics with general relativity and another against the structures he feels have prevented a needed revolution that would result in the next paradigm needed to advance our understanding of reality.The first, about the failures of string theory, is a case I find compelling but I don't have the expertise to evaluate his claims about string theory's specific faults. String theory has elegance but its lack of mathematical rigor, ability to generate testable claims, and almost cult-like status have always made me cheer for other view points.The second, about how modern academia prevents what he calls seers from thinking deeply to explain basic questions and challenge assumptions is both electric for being advanced by a scientist in a field where it normally isn't brought forward and quotidian in that the problems he posits exist in almost every other field and only newly came to the hard sciences.Smolin does demand his reader to keep track of topics but at the paragraph rather than chapter level with courteous redefining of terms and reminders. For easier to track arguments, this turns out to feel repetitive but mandated by rigor.

Excellent popular survey of the development of physics over the last century. Best introduction to and critique of string theory that I have seen. Although his thesis about contemporary physics is that its theories and arguments must be evidence-based, he praises Galileo for guessing that heliocentrism is correct: "Galileo was one of these; many of his arguments were wrong, and his opponents—the well-educated, philosophically reflective Jesuit astronomers of the time—easily punched holes in his thinking. Nevertheless, he was right and they were wrong." The reason that the Jesuit astronomers of Galileo's day "easily punched holes in his thinking" was that Galileo had no observations to confirm heliocentrism and no arguments that are respected as correct today. You would think that a physicist like Smolin would applaud the Jesuit astronomers for thinking, as he does, that ESP is no substitute for science, but he takes exactly the opposite tack, in keeping with the Grand Narrative so common among modern scientists. Galileo learned the heliocentric system from Jesuit astronomers (cf. Wallace, [i]Galileo, the Jesuits, and the Medieval Aristotle[/i]). Galileo asserted that heliocentrism was a matter of fact--which, as it turns out, was a correct assertion. But he rejected Kepler's ellipses, maintained uniform motion in perfect circles as the correct description of planetary motion, used more cycles and epicycles in his system than in the Ptolemaic system, and was less accurate than the Ptolemaic system in predicting planetary motion. His arguments from the tides show the influence of the moon's orbit around the earth, not the earth's orbit around the sun. Smolin can only praise Galileo and criticize the Jesuits by abandoning the principles upon which he evaluates modern physics.It is a small blemish on an otherwise helpful book. I suppose that if I weren't a Jesuit and a student of Wallace's, it wouldn't bother me so much.

early on, Smolin offhandedly mentions the social constructivists, who held that science is, just like any other social construction, just as valid as magic, religion, comedy, poetry, literature, psychology, or any other bunch of ideas that humans have spawned to describe their universe. Thereafter, he defends science as Tru-er than those, as it's based on observations of and predictions for objective phenomena, that are independent of human existence. Then, Smolin shows how reliance on background dependent theory, Heisenberg's uncertainty principle, and the failure of ever growing particle accelerators to foster major progress in the past thirty years has contradicted his own assertion. Smolin describes the folly of the contemporary devotion to the unobservable, untestable, incomplete theory that is the string, and relates how countless labor has been spent disproving different facets of the myriad versions of string theory.I find it astonishing yet expected that despite the fact that modern physics has come to a consensus that believes the fact that our observations are wholly dependent on our tools for observation, yet the scientists remain as arrogant as any pope, both claiming the Truth as their own, holding fast to the position of vanguard. Not that either position is to be rejected, I just don't think that any system of describing the world should be exulted. That pattern creates even more rigid tools for observation, and this is part of the reason Smolin is disappointed. The industry of thinking outside the box has become a tupperware dish as a result of its rampant arrogance.Lord Vader warns us, "Don't be too proud of this technological terror you've constructed. The ability to destroy a planet is insignificant next to the power of the Force," thus demonstrating the arrogance of the popes, and we all know where that got him.

wow. this is one hellaciously scathing, new-a/hole-ripping smackdown of a science book. the author wrote a mediocre book 6 years earlier ("3 roads to quantum gravity") in which he sat on the fence and actually had lots of very nice things to say about strings, even though he obviously thinks his own theory, loop quantum gravity, is a better bet. but this book is great. i learned a lot about string theory, which i had always thought was crap even though i didn't know much about it, and better yet i learned a bazillion concrete reasons to hate both string theory and string theorists. in all modesty, i think i am usually pretty good about not liking a piece of writing just because i agree with it. very often i read things whose conclusions i agree with, but if the arguments are crap, i still hate it. (e.g. i think bush is the worst president in history, but most of the bush-bashing i hear makes me crazy because it's so moronic, illogical, and unfounded.) ostensibly, the author claims that his main point is on how science gets done in general, and that string theory is just a case study, but it sure doesn't read that way. there is too much of his "sociological" analysis of the field of modern physics. he actually has lots of good data on faculty hirings and NSF granting policies, and he should just let the numbers speak for themselves. his most interesting general point is that around 1975, physics was ready for a revolutionary period, but for some reason the last 30 years have simply seen more "normal science", which is what clever, hardworking, competitive scientists do (what he calls "craftsmen"), as opposed to the revolutions which seem to be launched by deep-thinking rebels (what he calls "seers").highly informative and entertaining.

I first heard about string theory when I watched The Elegant Universe on television, coincidentally at the same time as I was reading the book of the same name. This really kick-started my amateur interest in physics and cosmology. I understood abstractly the problems with string theory and just assumed that eventually we would develop better instruments and experiments, and then test the theory's predictions. The Trouble with Physics critically evaluates the string theory research program, clarifies the specific problems and pitfalls within its claims, and thoughtfully debates whether the last 30 years have been harmful to the field of theoretical physics as a result. There is no technical maths in this book (good!) but the concepts are quite involved, and I found myself having to re-read parts occasionally. On the whole though, it was very accessible and Smolin writes in an engaging, no-nonsense way. The book is a broad survey of string theory, and also includes some history of relativity and quantum theory (as do all books of this kind, but here it's brief and Smolin doesn't go into extraneous detail). It was also refreshing to read something critical and deeply analytical, and I would be interested to read a direct rebuttal from the string community.I would have given 5 stars but didn't enjoy the final section as much as beginning/middle of the book. Although insight into the sociology of the physics and academic worlds is of merit, it just wasn't what I was looking for from this type of book. Maybe I was just fatigued at this point? In any case, for the physics alone it gets 5/5 and I strongly recommend it to other amateurs. Where a lot of popular science books are broadly positive, Smolin's voice here is very refreshing.

At first, despite my eagerness to read this book, I had difficulty reading it, not because it was too complex or I was unable to understand it, but because it challenged many of the things I thought I knew. In other words, Smolin was on-target with his point from the beginning, I just needed time to warm up and be receptive to his message.I've read a number of books on string theory and the math that goes into (and comes out of) this field. I was very impressed with what I had read to this point. Being a layperson without means to readily and thoroughly fact-check what was presented, I, instead, relied on reading information from multiple string-theory sources. As it came from multiple sources, I considered what I was being presented with at face value. But, at the same time, I knew there was more out there, and sought out a dissenting opinion.I'm very glad that this is the book I chose to get that alternate view. Smolin is convincing, shows support for his ideas, and is willing to acknowledge his own culpability in the faults he points out in the scientific community. He clearly makes his case without attacking individual scientists, though I suspect people "in-the-know" may be able to pick out a person or two from examples given. He's "been-there-and-done-that" giving him a broad basis of experience to draw from.While his message may not be well-received by the scientific community, it's certainly an important one. Science seems to be following an all-too-common trend where money and politics are dictating policy and procedure, and there is a growing disparity between those who follow the fad and those who strike out on their own with new ideas and who also challenge existing ones.

Before reading this book I heard many positive reviews from my friends, and having finished it I'm not disappointed. Not only does it give a very interesting history of the ideas of unification in physics (I did my project work in the UK on the original Kaluza Klein Theory), but also gives a glimpse of the community doing the science. Belief in what you do is necessary to do a good job, but belief can also backfire and become blind. This is most likely what has happened to String theory, that has had unfortunate repercussions for alternative theroies such as loop quantum gravity, twistors, and other visionary ideas. On top of this, Smolin also rightly critizises Universities to encourage "standard" Science and discourage visionaries from positions and jobs. This is a much more serious development and is (among other things) an effect of Big Science as Just Any Job, subject to tests, evaluations, peers, making a career for tenure, etc. I see this in my own country where scientists with original ideas have a hard time surviving in a bureaucratic tangle of committies, evaluations, politically correct research grant applications and heavy teaching burdens. I think the most interesting research these days come from hightech companies, and independent research insititutes like the Perimeter Institute and Santa Fe Institute for non-linear science, to mention a few. If I was financially independent with more brains than I actually have, I would open an institute like that. The research topic? Building artificial minds and trying to understand human and animal intelligence and cognition. And having a lot of fun at work without red tape getting in your way, which is what science and exploring the world is really about.

For a lay person this is a challenging read. Even though there is no math, Smolin is dealing with esoteric topics that are not easily understood. It is also two books in one: a discussion of the shortcomings of physics, particularly in reference to string theory, gravity and the quantum domain in the science part of the book; the second theme focusing on the sociological shortcomings that seem to be withholding talent and impeding progress within science and academia.Still, I feel I gained some insight into string theory, a field that has dominated the lives of many very intelligent scientists over several decades. As a lay person I have to rely on the ‘experts’ to translate as best they can, what certain theories are attempting to explain. Smolin, having worked and contributed to this field of study seems to have concluded that current theories are probably wrong. For all the effort and time put into this effort it remains only speculation and has been unable to produce verifiable results.Smolin uses this failure to highlight a real problem within his discipline, specifically its inability to recruit appropriate talent to explore other avenues of thought. He believes that sociological factors, like ‘groupthink’ are subverting the innovative talent that might move this discipline of science toward new and novel ways of thinking.I’ve hardly scratched the surface of the book’s contents but I was intrigued with the science and surprised by the critical views expressed by Somlin with regard to both the science and the establishment. But, inherent in the criticism, is a desire to point out ways to improve the system and the prospects for further scientific advancements.

Would Einstein be able to get a job in physics if he were alive today? Smolin says this is easy to answer because Einstein initially didn't find it easy to find work in physics back in his own time. Still, given the state of physics today, would a brilliant visionary physicist find work today if he didn't follow the prevailing trend? Probably not, Smolin laments. Smolin describes the "post-modern age" of physics where experimental results are replaced by mathematical equations, where a physicist who doesn't subscribe to string theory may find it difficult to find work at a university, where some string theorists are "crusaders rather than scientists." What has happened to physics and can we undo the damage? This book covers so many of the thoughts I have when I read about new developments in science. A little knowledge of physics is helpful going into the book, but probably not absolutely necessary. As a side note, I was disappointed but not surprised that Smolin doesn't see any parallel between string theory and evolution. If you take what Smolin says about what science should be doing and how a theory should be proven as fact, you could substitute "evolution" for "string theory" and much of what he said would make just as much sense. An even closer parallel between the two is that a biologist who even dares express doubt in evolution is likely to be blackballed in much the same way as (or likely far worse than) a non string theory physicist. Smolin mentions evolution and how it is clearly fact (just as string theorists say things like "any clear thinking person knows string theory must be true"). My personal belief is that science has lowered its standard of proof in any number of areas, of which string theory and evolution are the two most notable examples.

Although the book does get buried in attacks against String Theory, it's a necessity given the current state of theoretical physics. Although this problem has been exhibited in almost every other field of science as well - People have become to comfortable with an academic system that rewards 'correct' answers that are established, and 'incorrect' answers are ridiculed or laughed at.Looking at the history of science, one can see that many great scientists weren't the most impressive academically. In fact, most wouldn't be able to answer questions found in a standard Quantum Mechanics test today. Yet, science depends on the ability to fall down and pick oneself up in the pursuit of truth. The ability to ask deep questions and realize erroneous assumptions is also needed. Sometimes blind acceptance, closes the door to truth. It's no coincidence that the first 'scientists' were men of faith. When truth is the goal, you can find seekers in the most unlikely places. This book does a good job in highlighting many aspects of science that are simply accepted, yet not fully understood. There are even many other ideas out there that the book doesn't cover, or just grazes over... The Big Bang Theory for example is going to vehemently defended, even though most new theories require dark energy, or a new type of substance in the universe. Ideas accepted as the norm are suddenly taught as if they were proven, perhaps the 'politics as science' have taken their toll again. The Dark Ages were no different if you think about it - Except today; radical thought just assures you career death rather than actual death.

Oh, man, is this a brilliant book. Even if he's wrong and string theory is the Theory Of Everything, he's right that until we can connect it to experimental results, it is all just pretty math. The real test of a scientific hypothesis--and really, string theory is a hypothesis at present--is how well it predicts new phenomena, how well it gives new insights into existing theories, and how close it gets to the actual experimental results. Epicycles are perfectly fine for calculating the apparent position of planets in the sky, but epicycles don't make new predictions and epicycles do not lead to new (and experimentally valid!) understandings of the heavens.I highly recommend this book, not just for the lucid explanations of the weaknesses of string theory, or the brief outline of Doubly Special Relativity, but also for an excellent explanation of the problems of Big Science and why humanity has made so little progress in the last few decades in fundamental physics. Hint: too many 200 author Big Science papers, and too few deeply insightful explorations of alternative approaches by really smart people who are looking at the unexplained.If you love understanding nature, if you love physics, if you love to think about how the world can be like it is, you will love this book. Even if it is several years old, we still are missing critical pieces of the puzzle. Dr. Smolin takes you on a tour of what string theorists have accomplished, and it is substantial, along with the problems that remain, and they are nontrivial.Highly recommended.

I was attracted to this book because some e-forums I visit frequently have evangelical atheist types claiming science had all the answers and then rant that their atheistic perspective is the only logical way and how could any rational person see otherwise.The first half+ of the book examines the status of string theory over the past 40 years in all its varieties. Some theories using 25 dimensions and the most accepted using 11. It was slow reading but my engineering/science background helped me follow most of it. Have to admit I have a little trouble conceptualizing things that go beyond 3-D space and time. Smolin made the point early that US university physics departments are almost exclusively manned by string theorists. Another important point is that string theory has predicted nothing and has never been verified by experiment.The latter part of the book is more philosophical and questions the meaning of science showing it is not quite as obvious as one might think. He writes about how physic's research and funding is driven by what is fashionable, who one knows, and not by an openness to explore and pursue truth(although I hesitate to use that ambiguous word).I remember as an engineering graduate student who took some grad courses from the biochemistry-physics department noting the contrast between faculty. The engineering folks seemed to focus on problem solving and solutions and one felt somewhat of a comraderIe. The scientists really seemed arrogant, not too sociable and overly concerned with who's who.

Don't let the long title fool you. This is one of the finest works explaining physics and the academic world in which physicists live and work I have ever read! Some of the new stuff being worked on and the fundamental foundational questions being pondered is really cool and not easily accessed as this is the first I've heard of most of the ideas discussed. A clear look and explanation of string and M theory help me understand WHY I had a hard time understanding them in the first place because string theory is actually a multitude of theories (which I knew as just five) on the level of infinite and M theory is the supposed "Mother or Mystery" theory behind it while in reality having not even a rough skeleton of a theory and no predictions to falsify!I'm sure Smolin pissed off a lot of academics with this book but he made every effort to be fair and logical. Toward the end of the book he offers a few ways in which we can change the current mindset towards supporting the revolutionaries rather than marginalizing them as the current structure encourages.A must read for anyone interested in physics. This is the fourth book I've read by Smolin and with each one I become more impressed not by his genius but by his ability to allow me to visualize the concept with excellent descriptions and finely written and edited work. Many works on this topic tend to be sloppy in the technical writing or lacking in the ability to maintain interest because of too much technical over theoretical and a bad case of "dryness."

Lee Smolin presents: surprises from the real world!The cosmic background radiation fluctuates at the level of a few parts in a hundred thousand. Think of these ripples as sound waves echoing from the violent birth of the universe. The peaks in the CMB angular power spectrum graph indicate to LS and others that "the matter filling the early universe was resonant, like the head of a drum or the body of a flute... The wavelengths of the resonant modes tell us how big the universe was when it first became transparent: that is, when the initial hot plasma devolved, or 'decoupled', into separate realms of matter and energy three hundred thousand years after the big bang."There seems to be a 'preferred direction' to the cosmic background radiation, which LS and his buddies have nicknamed 'the axis of evil.'LS invites some speculation on these numbers:R = the radius of the universe observable from Earth via lightc = the velocity of light (distance divided by time)R/c ≈ present age of the universec/R = absurdly low 'note' whose pitch is one oscillation per age of the universec²/R = rate of acceleration of the universe's expansionThis is quite close to the acceleration stars experience at the distance from a galaxy's center where you have to start taking dark matter into account to accurately model their trajectory. Hmm.

The more I read of Lee Smolin, the more I appreciate him. This book was his warning cry that theoretical physics was entering a cul de sac, and risking having nothing meaningful to say about the nature of reality because of its infatuation with elegant mathematics over testable hypotheses. I was struck by his using the term "postmodern physics" to describe this situation. Indeed, the faddish, fragmented, highly abstract world of contemporary physical theory has its parallel elsewhere in academics. We're all living in the enormous aftermath of some hope for a grand synthesis that never happened. Why would anyone who's not a scientist care about these things? Because science, particularly theoretical physics and evolutionary biology when taken together, is attempting to give us our origin story and our place in the scheme of things without the kind of social coercion and enforced ignorance that political ideology or religion do. It's a tremendously worthwhile thing - if it doesn't become another unaccountable priesthood in its own right. And if it is honest about its limitations - its ability to create useful models of reality, but not to duplicate or replace it. But if science is becoming its own Church, full of careerism, orthodoxy, and arrogance, then its helpfulness is reduced and its danger is increased. Physics has obtained too much power over the physical world not to be humble. Smolin's is a welcome voice of caution and hope from the inside.

This must be ranked as one of the most courageous works of modern semi-popular science writing. Smolin, himself a very-well-accredited physicist, analyzes in detail the development of modern string theory, which is believed by many in the theoretical physics community to be the best candidate of a "theory of everything" that will quantum mechanics and general relativity. Smolin documents in detail how string theory has failed to deliver on its grand promise. Despite 25 years of concerted effort by some of the world's best minds, the theory still has not yielded any crisp, quantifiable, testable results for the real world. Smolin also summarizes and then ridicules the attempts by Susskind and others in the string theory community, who have suggested that the "answer" to the long-running paradox of why the universe is seemingly so specially designed for life (overcoming odds of 10^120 or more) is to posit an ensemble of over 10^500 parallel universes, so that our existence is an instance of the "anthropic principle" -- if the universe weren't just so, we wouldn't be around to be discussing the issue. Smolin emphasizes that such reasoning is the epitome of an unfalsifiable notion, and therefore has no business being entertained, much less endorsed, in modern science.

"The Trouble with Physics" by Lee Smolin who is a theoretical physicist argues that physics has lost its way. Lee Smolin suggests that there are too many theories and no solid proof that these ideas of extra dimensions, multiple universes and strings actually can or do exist. Speculations dominate the field of physics and Lee Smolin is concerned that it is suffocating the progress of science. What is needed is to move beyond the string theory and look for something new; question the theories and search out new big ideas.While reading this book I had to have my iPhone with me and I was constantly looking terminology and theories up on the internet. My knowledge of physics did not allow me to read the book without a lot of help from Wikipedia. I was rewarded for my effort for I did learn more about the science of physics than I thought I would. I got the general feeling from the book that Lee Smolin is bitter towards the string theory community and feels they dominate the world of physics and that this world needs to move onto new ideas. I found his attitude a bit supercilious and found it slightly agitating.If you are interested in physics and want to learn more about the community of physicist then grab your iPhone and read away.

Smolin really delivers with this volume. It's pretty weighty, but the concepts are presented very neatly and without a lot of the technical jargon. The real strength of this book is Smolin's real objectivity when surveying the landscape of modern physics research. With all the hype over String Theory, it's nice to see someone take a step back from the giddying beauty and symmetries of the theory(ies) and provide a realistic assessment as to whether or not the theory has delivered. I think some of the best parts of this book are the last few chapters that deal with the sociological and philosophical aspects of science in general for the 21st century. Smolin's insights into the profession, particularly his critique for how new graduates are hired, given tenure, or research grants are pointed and disconcerting. Whether or not String Theory is the real deal, or the worst fad in physics since the aether, Smolin's approach to the subject is one that is well wroth embracing. The lesson that professionals and amateurs alike can take from this is never to put all your eggs in one basket. There've just been too many precedents of fundamental assumptions being overthrown in the past 300 years.

I just finished reading The Trouble With Physics by Lee Smolin. It is a GREAT book. Now what has this to do with innovation and start-ups? Well I see a link: In my book I refer to Thomas Kuhn, the author of the “structure of scientific revolutions”. Indeed Innovation and Research have similarities in the way they progress. The specific topic he focuses on is the lack of progress in physics. Don’t we have a similar issue with innovation? I also quoted Pitch Johnson, one of the grandfathers of venture capital who wrote: “Democracy works best when there is this kind of turbulence in the society, when those not well-off have a chance to climb the economic ladder by using brains, energy and skills to create new markets or serve existing markets better then their old competitors.”Smolin considers Science needs two ingredients: ethics and imagination. If the established science and scientists prevent the emergence of young people and new ideas, there might be a crisis. It is what he analyses brilliantly in his book. (By the way, his book tells much more, it is a really great book). When Silicon Valley people such as Joe Costello and Richard Newton claimed that Silicon Valley needs to take more risks and that greed is more important than ethics, I see similarities…

A little known Physicist Called Theodre Kaluza was toying with Einstein's Equations for General Theory of Relativity in four dimensions and what he ended up with was James Clarkes Maxwells Equations for Electro-Magnetism. Thus was born the idea that all forces in the universe could be explained by adding extra dimensions to space. Today there is this string theory,with 10 spacial dimensions and one dimension of time, which ofcourse seems Bizzare. Here we are being bombared with the idea of multiverses(multiple Universes), curled up dimension and blah.. blah.. blah. The Author Lee Smolin cautions against Physics going hayware, in the absence of precise predictions or observations. Even now the elusive Higgs Boson has not been found after many a collision experiment in the particle accelarators. In the absence of repeatable experiments, it is just a theory, mathematically made consistent however.This book explores the history of many attempts to unify all the field force. Like Prof Walter Lewin of MIT says while teaching MIT freshmen, Newtons Laws of Gravitation Qoute "Can we prove Newtons Law of Gravitation, No! but results of all experiments, are consistent with the Law. Hence we accept the law" unqoute

The primary reason I have read this book was as research for my thesis. My goal while writing it was to evaluate the philosophical background of string theory and whether it constitutes a science or a philosophy.Mr. Smolin is very knowledgeable when it comes to string theory and does an excellent job of explaining its fundamentals in the first half of the book. He goes through the historical predecessors of string theory, takes his time to explain all of them using diagrams and analogies. For this he deserves credit.For the second part of his book however he somewhat goes off the rails (much like my thesis). As seen from the title Smolin is not a fan of string theory. While his discussions of many of the philosophical objections are interesting and well written, towards the end he disgresses into contested claims surrounding the funding of string theory and its allocation of researchers.I still fully recommend that you read this book, it offers an excellent overview of string theory and is often insightful. You should know beforehand however that Mr. Smolin is a strong proponent of something called quantum loop gravity (QLG) as an alternative to string theory.It should also be noted that Mr. Smolin is considered to be one of the founders of quantum loop gravity.

This book is an excellent antidote to all the string theory madness that has gripped the public's attention since Brian Greene's publication of The Elegant Universe in 1999. Smolin exposes the gaping holes in string theory's attempt to ascent to a bona fide Theory of Everything by revealing the philosophical hoops string theorists jump through to maintain the hope that the theory possesses testability or revelatory power. While his critique of the science behind string theory is devastating to the layman familiar only with Mr. Greene's work, more interesting is the last fourth of the book, in which he attacks the institutions of science at the major research producing universities for inherent cronyism, sexism and orthodoxy, tying these trends to the puzzling fact that a theory with so many holes can be the only game in town when it comes to research dollars and Phd's granted.I would recommend you read Brian Greene's The Elegant Universe first to get a handle on String Theory, then maybe toss some Michio Kaku in there to really get yourself excited about the wild and wacky universe that Lee Smolin will summarily destroy for you. It's worth it.

Although the actual science covered is quite arcane and might require the reader to have a really good grasp on the rigidly defined (or not so rigidly, the stuff is really intricate) concepts (which I probably haven't), Smolin succeeds in pointing out the flaws of string theory (essentially that it's not background-independent, i.e. it does not make any specific predictions about the the shape of the background (the number of dimensions and their shape etc.) which means that there are actually many different possible string theories with different configurations of those parameters that have so far not been convincingly shown to be the result of one overarching theory, and so on, it's really rather complicated). Most importantly though, Smolin illustrates the negative influence of the American model of academia: He shows that it discourages the exceptional thinkers that refuse to do science in the mainstream way by its selection mechanisms that mainly focus on financial prospects. Being an optimist, Smolin gives an outline how to overcome the institutional and sociological problems. Being a pessimist, I doubt that this proposal will have any real influence.

Unlike other books dealing with modern science, Smolin’s “trouble with physics” does not go much into science, but rather reads like a philosophy book with obbligato science parts. The biggest concern of the book is with the structuralization of modern science and the negative impact of ‘doing normal science’. Smolin is not writing against string theory per se, rather he writes against academic obsession and against the prejudices of string theorists who refuse to see that they may be wrong. In general, the thoughts of Smolin show how easily creative progress can be suffocated through peer reviews and academic bureaucracy which promotes technical normalcy rather than creativity. Reading Smolin’s book makes you appreciate the thoughts of Einstein even more, since Einstein never managed to get a real academic career and the strength of relativity’s revolution is that it is an independently worked out theory which was worked out free from the pressure of performance and instead relied on true genius and creativity.

Really enjoyed it, even as -- and perhaps because -- I struggled so much due to my lack of background knowledge. I wanted to finish this, and learn, and was propelled forward by Smolin's thoughtful and positive (but unafraid to speak his mind) tone and, I am unashamed to admit, the similarity of his position on rational discourse with my own. His anti-polarization attitude really does represent the scientific mindset to me.Now I'm going to have to read more about the pro-String Theory (or at least pro-Superstring Theory) side of the argument. It would be inappropriate for a scientific thinker to hear only one side and decide that he's heard enough!And another great thing this book led me to: it has been years since I have struggled through reading like I struggled through this and Why Beauty Is Truth. I think it can only make me a better teacher to have empathy and not mere sympathy for students who read but don't (fully) understand.

The Trouble with Physics is that it's complicated. Really, really complicated. I finally gave up the fight. I'm fine with physics up till about Einstein, and even that is a bit tough, but this lost me. The writing was entertaining and pretty clear, but the concepts were mind-boggling. It would have helped if he had included a glossary of all those weird terms - Higgs boson, lepton, etc - and maybe a timeline of physicists and their discoveries, so I could reference all the names. But really, I just don't understand this string theory stuff, and the more I think about it, the more my brain hurts.I'm not sure who I would recommend this to. If you are already interested in string theory, pro or con, you have probably already read this book. If you are like me, just interested in science in general, but with no formal training, you'll probably be lost a few chapters in. But if it sounds good, by all means, give it a try. I don't think it was the writing that was the problem. It's just that my brain is now tied in knots. Or donuts. Or wormholes. Or something like that.

String theory has dominated theoretical physics for two decades, with the vast majority of funding available to the field being poured into its construction and resolution. However, after so many years it is still unresolved, and criticized by some to indeed be unprovable. Lee Smolin’s investigation into the state of modern physics research is an intriguing, and sometimes bitter, criticism of how one unproven theory has come to completely dominate an entire field of science. He is not opposed to further research into string theory, but he laments not only the lack of support but also the outright dismissal of any researcher brave enough to investigate alternate theories. While he at times perhaps overstates his case, Smolin is to be commended for his courage in exposing the truth that real-world scientists do not always live up to their own myth of the unemotional, neutral observer of evidence, but can indeed display all the prejudices and irrationality of typical human beings. Advice from this book: don’t necessarily believe everything you hear or read, even if a scientist says it.

I am reminded of Arthur Schopenhauer's quote: "Talent hits a target no one else can hit. Genius hits a target no one else can see." And the problem Smolin points out plaguing the world of physics (at least at the time of it's publication), is that no one trusts the guy who's interested in a target everyone else can't see. Though written for a lay audience, unless you have an interest in theoretical physics, you might find yourself slogging through the meat of the book as I sometimes did. Perhaps the most interesting section was the last (Part IV), his commentary on the current state of science in general and physics in particular. University physics departments, specifically large ones, have become sclerotic and risk averse. Rather than bet on a budding scientist with fresh ideas, the money - and tenure track positions - usually goes to the safe bet, that is the graduate students who choose to follow fashionable research. Sure and steady wins the race, or in this case, makes for happier faculty, but the field as a whole suffers as a result.

Prof. Smolin addresses a problem that began to bother me in graduate school: particle physics seemed to be becoming dominated by theories that could not be disproved by experiment. Smolin claims that now, some thirty years later, the case remains and has become entrenched as the mainstream to the point that no real breakthrough has been made in the past thirty years.The book describes the problem and advocates that we need to change the way we fund science to allow more dissenting views to be worked on. He faults the scientific academy with developing a system that stifles creativity.Prof. Smolin is quite repetitive. This book would benefit from editing, but his point is clear. He documents his claims with copious footnotes. He states proposed solutions rather than just bemoaning the problem.Non scientists who could wade through, or skim over, the science in this book would gain insight as to how science is really done today.

It's clear to anyone (in the UK) who follows the news that the study and teaching of physics is in something of a crisis. My old university department felt the effects a couple of years ago as it became the latest physics department to be closed down.Lee Smolin appears to be arguing that that's a result of deeper problems in physics. Arguing that for two centuries physics experienced major breakthroughs every 25-30 years until now, he explores the current pressing questions and attempts to answer them. Despite having contributed to string theory himself he is scathing of its move away from predictive, testable science and of its chances of success.Smolin's book is well worth a read for anyone who wants to get to grips with what's happening in the world of cosmology and particle physics, and probably essential for anyone who wants to grapple with the place science is playing within modern education and wider society.

This is a book about science, rather than a book on science. Lee Smolin gives a recap of his experiences in theoretical physics over the last 30 years; he believes that string-theory has become a dangerously dominant paradigm that chokes off independent research paths. He touches on his misgivings about string theory, and gives snapshots of alternative ideas, the physicists behind them and their struggles at getting university support and funding. Smolin makes and argument that it might be a good idea for universities to look at investing in research scientist in the same way that investors look at Venture Capital strategy (9 out of 10 can fail, but that 1 payoff more than covers for it). The Trouble With Physics is, on the whole, an interesting read-- but I can't be sure whether Smolin has delved into a bit of hyperbole in his main concern. Those on the outside of dominant paradigms regularly have similar worries, but science seems to move forward anyway.

I read this book as a counterpoint to the string theory craze. I had read a few string theory books, but I wanted to see what the other side had to say about the subject. Smolin makes many good points, but in the end I think he comes off as a rather fustrated naysayer. While he does discuss a lot of theories that are alternatives to string theory, and he does point out a lot of string theories (very publizied) holes, he spends a lot of time laymenting about the state of the physics community and the petty personal issues that keep seemingly good science from taking place. When you think of scientists, you think of people with open minds, a willingness to listen to ideas, and a strong conviction for the truth. You wouldn't think of some kind of Totalitarian dictatorship, promoting the pro-string theory party line against all odds, and devoted to keeping down the desenters. You might find this in governemnt, but this is what Smolin describes in taking place in labratories everyday.

In The Trouble with Physics, Lee Smolin, founder of the Perimeter Institute of Theoretical Physics in Ontario, Canada, and the author of several popular science books, including The Life of the Cosmos and Three Roads to Quantum Gravity, takes a complex debate on a highly theoretical topic and makes it accessible and interesting to the general public. With gusto, the author describes the infighting and politics that hinder progress in physics. Opinions vary on the success of Smolin's call to action in sections where he skewers his colleagues in theoretical physics for their shortsightedness. Reviewers, however__most of them physicists__tend to agree that string theorists' inability to empirically test their results will continue to undermine their effortsThis is an excerpt from a review published in Bookmarks magazine.

1st half: history and desc of string theory, reasons why it doesn't seem to be working out--pretty technical although no math; 3rd quarter: desc of alternatives to string theory being pursued by some; 4th quarter: scathing indictment of hiring and grant awarding practices current in academic physics and their stultifying effect on innovation and consequent achievement of goals of scientific inquiry, i.e., how they're counterproductive to the very thing the physicists are supposed to be doing.  An excellent and insightful writer. I'm wondering whether the tight hold of senior academicians over the purse strings and direction of research and thus careers of younger scientists isn't due to the general aging of the population and the growing proportion of older workers staying on rather than retiring and opening positions for younger ones. This would not be confined to physics nor to academe. It would be interesting to know if there are folks in other fields who feel as Smolin does.

I've always had an interest in theoretical physics (although I hated the math that accompanied it) and so the recent spate of books by physicists who make physics come alive in terms laypeople can understand has been a godsend. I've read books by Brian Greene, Stephen Hawking, and others, but I have to say this one was one of my favorites because there was an element of someone IN the field talking not only about the discoveries that have been made, but commenting in a more holistic way about the field itself and where they saw it heading in the future. Lee Smolin does a great job of showing the reader what string theory is as well as why so many physicists seem to have accepted it, and - more importantly - what repercussions this acceptance will have for the field of physics in general. Overall, this was an immensely readable book that anyone with even a passing interest in physics will probably enjoy.

Interesting discussion of a number of the String Theories. Wish I could say I understood all of them but did enjoy reading about them and learning of their diversities. I found the discussion of the problems in academia and the governments methods of choosing "up and coming young physicists" extremely interesting. The reasoning for why we have not made significant advances in the field sound painfully true. The senior scientist doing the recruiting, hire only those promoting their scientific agenda, making it very difficult for dissenting opinions to see the light of day much less giving new ideas an opportunity for future research or discussion at scientific conferences. Funding for the maverick scientist and his original ideas seems to be nonexistent, leaving the field of physics wallowing in a pool of so far unproven theories, with little hope of definitive proof or new solution in the near future.

Amazon review:In this illuminating book, the renowned theoretical physicist Lee Smolin argues that fundamental physics -- the search for the laws of nature -- is losing its way. Ambitious ideas about extra dimensions, exotic particles, multiple universes, and strings have captured the public’s imagination -- and the imagination of experts. But these ideas have not been tested experimentally, and some, like string theory, seem to offer no possibility of being tested. Yet these speculations dominate the field, attracting the best talent and much of the funding and creating a climate in which emerging physicists are often penalized for pursuing other avenues. As Smolin points out, the situation threatens to impede the very progress of science. With clarity, passion, and authority, Smolin offers an unblinking assessment of the troubles that face modern physics -- and an encouraging view of where the search for the next big idea may lead.

A very good book. It's interesting how simultaneously I have been listing to Leonard Susskinds lectures on string theory as apparently Lee and Leonard have disagreed on topics in physics in the past. Leonard favors string theory as the ultimate theory while Lee thinks that an alternative must be pursued because string theory doesn't answer all the questions it was intended to answer.I think Lee delivers a good message though on the status of educational and research physics. The trap of doing things for money and not for discovery is plaguing the college landscape quickly. He makes a good point of how no university would allow another Einstein because of the high risk nature of the research and imaginative visions. Colleges are like a business and want to minimize risks to gain maximized profit. High risk could potentially mean no profit. Lee's remarks to the advancement of science will be in small steps as no one seems to be willing to take great risks anymore.

I've recently recognised my superb eagerness to review bad books in contrast to this almost magical tendency to be stunned speechless by a good one. So given that I've avoided writing a review for this for almost 1.5 months, it's quite obvious how far in the latter category this book was to me.That being said, I've mostly forgotten most of the technical discussions in this book, though a lot of what was said has somehow managed to filter down into my subconscious, enough for a rough understanding the state of theoretical physics today.************So Smolin sees these physics' great unsolved problems:1. Quantum Gravity: Uniting quantum mechanics with general relativity2. Making some (actual) sense of quantum mechanics3. Unification: Explaining all the particles and forces under one banner4. Explaining the values of the free constants in the standard model5. Explaining the presence of "dark matter" and "dark energy".

Smolin's thesis is that there have been no big breakthroughs in theoretical physics in 30 years, and that the culture of academia is to blame. String theory has been in fashion for the last few decades, but while its promise seems to have run out, it still dominates almost all research programs. Smolin makes his case against academia pretty well, if a bit redundantly, but I was more interested in reading about the details of string theory and why it hasn't delivered on its promise. Unfortunately this book is aimed at a general audience so it uses metaphors and hand-waving rather than getting into the math behind the concepts, and I didn't get a solid enough grasp to really judge his arguments. Perhaps I should get some physics textbooks, but if a conversational discussion of the topics is all you want, then this book will be fine for you.

The sorry state of today's particle physics: lots of unfinished theories, and many unexplained phenomena these theories cannot explain either. For example, cosmic ray detectors occasionally detect protons with energy as high as 50 Joules, even though special relativity says that for protons with energy above 10 Joules the cosmic microwave background radiation should be blue-shifted so much it would appear as gamma rays, with which the protons would interact, produce pions, and lose energy. Did these protons come from somewhere nearby so they haven't had a chance to interact with the background radiation, or is special relativity wrong at such high energies? No one has any idea. Much of the book consists of attacks on string theory and string theorists, but I don't know if the alternatives to string theory are any better.

Smolin discusses what the major problems in physics are today, both specific challenges presented by the science and what he perceives as political problems clamping down on creativity. He discusses the history of string theory and its later manifestations (unfortunately the book is already dated). He finally discusses some possible alternatives to string theory. I appreciated learning about some cool experiments being done and some surprising possibilities, such as fundamental constants changing in time among other things, and also appreciated the the critical eye on the popular superstring theory. Aside from that though I was surprisingly bored, mostly with the exhaustive description of politics in the world of academia. I wanted merely to learn some cosmology and was uninterested in the polemic, even if appropriate.

This book is amazing through the first couple of hours. The author essentially describes the devastation left in the wake of positivism and other modern subjectivism, without using those words or addressing it quite so philosophically. He advocates a return to "realism" (not in the philosophic sense, but what should be more properly called objectivity) in science. His tracing of the history of the science and how the very modern era, at least in the age of string theory, was really fascinating.I gave up because at about the half way point, I started glazing over as the ideas he is talking about require knowing a lot more physics than I do or than I aspire too. I strongly recommend the first half of the book to anyone, and quite possibly the second half will be wonderful for people more well-versed than I am in advanced physics.

Although the largest portion describes the current state of the string conjectures that dominate theoretical physics, the heart of this book lies in the final few chapters. In the end this is a book most concerned with what science is fundamentally and how it is practiced. Smolin's very brief overview of the basic issues of philosophy of science, his own thesis of science as "an ethical and an imaginative community" , and his critique of peer review and the politics of tenure are refreshing enough by themselves to make this book worth reading. The Trouble with Physics is a nice counterpoint to the many, mostly un-critical, popularizations of 'string theory' which are written for non-physicists.

This book confronts issues in the front and center of theoretical physics. With some basic knowledge in quantum mechanics, an average reader can benefit from reading this book. It is written as a critique to modern physics, string theory in particular, but it tells a great story of the history of the string theory, as well as what it is and how it ran into deep trouble. A theory invented to preserve the beauty and consistency of theoretical physics, the author argued, it has evolved into a nightmarishly complex creature. Lee Smolin may not be the craftiest writer out there, but his scientific mind shines through in the rigorous, structured approach to storytelling. Highly recommended to anyone who cares to learn the fundamental characteristics of our world.

Great book that demystifies the grandiose claims of the string theorist who still have nothing to show after 20+ years of dominating the cutting edge of physics, unless they retreat in theology with the Multiverse taking place of God - so many are succumbing to the attitude do not ask too many questions since the Multiverse ordained it, we just have to describe it the best v(ie the way math tells us, reality notwithstanding).Basically the attitude of the Church theologians of the middle ages with abstract math taking place of the parsing of the Bible - very clever and great arguments but nothing to do with reality...Before reading any popular book on the edges of physics , read this one first to see why you should not take in the hype

Interesting book that raises questions not only about the correctness of string theory but also about what it is to be a scientific theory at all and about social aspects of the enterprise of science. There are times when Smolin comes across as someone with a grudge, but he asks some important questions and I've not yet seen a decent rebuttal. The physics was too much for me (will someone please find a way to explain gauge invariance to non-physicists, for example?) I also found it interesting how the endeavours described in the book sounded so little like physics and so much like applied mathematics. Do physicists actually do any physics these days or do they just prove mathematical theories that are relevant to the physical theories?

Amazing book, very inspiring and informative. It explains why the progress in physics before 1970-s was so stunningly successful and what exactly went wrong since then.The author examines a few influential ideas in physics and follows their historical development. He refines the key properties which the successful ideas possessed, such as the ability to make new predictions, robustness etc., and then examines the concepts of modern nowadays physics in light of these properties. The most enjoyable thing about this book is the right proportion of skepticism and enthusiasm to various (sometimes rather crazy) physical ideas, producing a particularly lucid sense of reality. This is a must-read for all people who like the path of reason and appreciate clear thinking.

This is a decent book if your into theoretical physics, I happen to not be one of those people. I honestly thought I was going to get more out of this book, hear some things about quantum particles and forces but instead Smolin talks about imaginary dimensions and wormholes with infinite values. Despite that, I find it troublesome that these people put so much effort in thinking what the universe is like, but seem to totally forget about practical experimentation which supports their theories. This is basically what happens when you let the imaginations of physics majors run wild unchecked (Smolin makes a good point about that in this book). Good read if you are knowledgeable about physics and want to know what's going on in the physics community right now, if not stay away from this.

"The Trouble With Physics" is actually three different treatises: first, Lee Smolin, a renown theoretical physicist, explains five major questions that modern physicists have not been able to answer. Second, he explains why none of main research efforts has been able to unify theories of electromagnetism, quantum mechanics, and gravity. Finally, he offers an editorial on how the culture and politics of academia is preventing new research initiatives from happening. I was able to follow the first three chapters after the new concept load (vocabulary) became too heavy for me to casually absorb. It will have to wait until I can listen with the pause button in one hand and a physics dictionary in the other. The third section is easily understood and information everyone should hear

This was an excellent read and I highly recommend it for any young science enthusiast heading in the academic minefield that is theoretical/experimental physics. I originally picked this book up because the author holds an opposition to one of the most dominating theories of our generation, String Theory, but I found now I have many more questions than answers. What I expected to be insane ramblings of a bitter academic turned out to be extremely thoughtful and provocatively insightful viewpoints on the current state of science, inside and out. I will be picking up more of this author's work, starting with his book on Quantum Loop Gravity! Thank you Lee Smolin for opening my eyes to a whole multiverse of new possibilities!

I quite enjoyed this book, although I have to admit that I did skip through a few parts. I thought the first and last sections of this book were the best. I felt it got a little bogged down during the "A Brief History of String Theory" section of the book, which is where I tended to skip through parts. I enjoyed the history of "The Unfinished Revolution", and his description of the physics academic community in "Learning from Experience." He also does a good job showing alternatives to string theory with the section "Beyond String Theory." It is a good read, and quite enlightening on a part of society I was unfamiliar with.

An excellent discussion from the point of view of a member of the physics community of the contemporary state of affairs in theoretical physics. Although not recommended as in introductory primer on string theory--you will follow the story better if you already have a basic lay understanding of relativity, quantum theory, and string theory--this is an excellent overview of the story of the last two decades of progress in physics and a frank evaluation of where we stand. The last half of the book, which discusses alternatives to string theory and examines the sociological issues behind its dominance for the past two decades, is particularly good.

I think I got this book free on Amazon. It was supposed to be a layman's guide to string theory. I'd like to think that I have more than the layman's understanding of physics, but much of it was way over my head. He starts out good, explaining, pretty clearly, what the current major issues are for today's physicists. He lost me in the detailed explanations of the current string theories, and of quantum gravity. The last third of the book seemed very out of place, as it's pretty much a rant about how the modern University education system is failing to produce or support free thinkers.Not recommended.

Smolin surveys the current state of fundamental theoretical physics and finds some problems. String theory has dominated the field for decades but has yet to produce a new experimental prediction. Furthermore, there is no real string theory as such, but rather an enormous number of possible theories which may or may not be unified under the even more speculative M-Theory.Smolin challenges the scientific community to embrace alternate approaches to fundamental physics and introduces a number of them, some he has worked on and others he has not.This is a very, very good book.

I tried with this book, I really did. There is lots of interesting stuff if you're interested in the modern history of scientific inquiry particularly in "Big Idea" physics. But good luck finding it in between endless technical details of mind-numbingly convoluted theories. I think the problem is that the book is neither popular science which is shined up for a non-scientific audience nor is it hard science with all the math for people who want to deeply understand. It lives in an unfortunate middle space of deeply explained theories with "you'll have to take my word for it on the math." Either way, it put me to sleep on the train more than once.

I had not been paying any attention to modern findings in Physics, but this book did a great job of "catching me up" with what has been going on and where we are in the state of theoretical physics. I enjoyed the book but it was a bit slow and trying at points. Still, the author is to be commended for making so much complexity comprehensible to an audience that might not have physics training at a college level.I know that I will greet future announcements from the world of theoretical physics with some greater skepticism after reading this book. Our ability to imagine things which are elegant (but not provable) needs some reigning in, I think.

I didn't think he was quite as comprehensible as some other popular science authors I've read. OTOH, he covers a lot of ground, explaining a number of different theories and concepts in a way that most other books don't attempt. Additionally, the final quarter of the book that uses the philosophy of science and common sense to diagnose and suggests solutions for problems he sees in the physics academy is terrific. Interesting, easy to grasp, and, I felt, broadly applicable to not only academic disciplines but life. Without this final section, I would've said I felt it was two star read, but instead I think it's a three star read.

Interesting and compelling, but suffers from some organization problems and an unclear sense of purpose that I found somewhat distracting. I felt that the author or editors were very unsure about how much scientific information to include. It is lost somewhere between social commentary on the state of the field and education and a being a layman's guide to high level physics.Still, it has had a noticeable effect on my inner musings, which is no small feat. I would recommend reading it, but try to think of it more as a collection of related facts and opinions rather than as a "book."

Luke Janes got me this book for my birthday. He knew I'd like it because I'm a science nerd, and I'm especially interested in theoretical physics. This book, however, is about a lot more than that. Lee Smolin (one of my new heroes) not only challenges the state and direction of the modern study of physics, he does in the context of our (humanity's) responsibility to seek out truth and make sense of the universe around us. It's a sober analysis of modern physics, but a very hopeful one. A good counterpoint to Brian Greene's string theory orthodoxy.

The book starts as a review of String Theory and it's clear that the author believes that the emperor has no clothes, for a variety of reasons but mainly because it's a theory that adapts to the facts rather than making new, compelling and testable predictions. Later on the theme is broadened to an insiders critique of the politics and practice of physics. String Theory has become a kind of dogma, and if it's as badly off track as Smolin suggests then this is a huge drag on making progress in any other direction.

I did not read every word of this very fine book, since I had already gotten the gist of string theory from Brian Greene's "The Elegant Universe" (and had my brain exploded by "space-tearing phase transitions"), and had also gotten the essentials of the failures of string theory from other sources. Lee Smolin is a fine writer and a fascinating thinker, and I found the later chapters of the book to be the most interesting, wherein he speculates about new ideas in physics, what kind of people physicists are, what science is, why we should care.

are you a closet science/physics nerd? wonder what the real deal is with these things called String Theory and Quantum Mechanics? well, it might just be that they don't actually have any true scientific grounding.Lee Smolin suggests that physics has lost its way since the early 20th century. His case is convincing. If you are a mathematician, this book will probably piss you off.And don't fret when you reach the dense chapters describing modern string theory. it's convoluted because the theory is convoluted. that's exactly what he's trying to show.

Not bad. It does what I like: present the dominant theory, challenge it, make me think. But it also is really a kind of inside baseball, exploring the reasons why String Theory came to prominance and its reasons for stifling the academic debate, precluding alternate routes of discovery, and the role academic politics has played in that process. In conclusion, the argument isn't as refined as The Black Hole War; I'm glad I read it, but wouldn't really recommend it to anyone else, unless they were actually in physics.

This book had a great overview of physics ("post-modern") from around the 1970s. It was a good (but sometimes repetitive) look at what it takes to make a revolutionary change in science, and how string theory has failed to do that. One chapter looked at the problems with academic/grant/tenure system which had some interesting points. I like Tim Ferris' Science of Liberty a bit better, but there are some parallels in this book -- an interesting divergence was Smolin's embrace of Feyerabend and Ferris' total dismisal of Feyerabend.

This thoughtful and studious book looks at five great problems of theoretical physics:1. The attempt to combine general relativity and quantum theory, to form a complete theory of nature.2. Resolving the problems in quantum mechanics--by fixing it or inventing a new theory.3. Though various particles and forces can be unified in limited theories, we need a unification theory that explains them all.4. Explaining how the values of free constants in particle physics are chosen in nature.5. Explaining dark matter and dark energy.

This book is Definitely not what I had expected it to be, but it is informative nonetheless. At numerous occasions Author got too technical for me, especially when he was trying to explain various claims that String Theorists make about Modern Physics and its future. Again, it is definitely good to know that there are people like the Author, who do really think of Consequences of backing Theories that are too Risky and might not turn out to be fruitful. It definitely made me question very simple facts about many things I learned about our Universe.

Smolin is a well-known string theory (ST) skeptic, and he makes some good points in this book about why the ST case is not very solid (even if it may be part of the Ultimate Truth, currently it is practically non-falsifiable).The physics discussion is interesting (even if he sometimes simplifies things so much that it is hard to understand the connection between various concepts); his rambling on about the sociology of the physics community is must less interesting. Yes, I know what 'groupthink' means...

Overall, a good book. It's got a lot of digressions and I won't lie, I mostly read it for the sick string theory burns, but it was interesting and engaging all the same. The long chapters about academic politics towards the end were both annoying and a relief - annoying, because they were repetitive, and a relief, because they're not technical. If you like pop science books I'd say give this one a try, though it's as much philosophy as "this is cool stuff for laymen about how the universe works."

I really enjoyed this book. It had an easy flowing prose albeit one that had some 'tough' terms like gluons,ferminions and their distant cousins. This book confirmed my gut instinct about string theory. The first time I came across it and was trying to wrap my head around the calabi yau manifold, I kept thinking nature cannot be this complicated. Its nice to see that respected physicists also concur. String theorists should go back to the drawing board and come up with something better and not conjure up fancy stuff that cannot be proven.

Imagine a physics page-turner! I really got into this book. Thanks to Lee Smolin, I finally understand how Einstein's basic theory of relativity works (or at least I did while I was reading the book). I got a little lost as the string theory stuff spiraled out in complexity, but that's part of his point -- a theory that hard to understand and impossible to disprove may not be a workable theory at all.

Quite an amazing book. It took a while to get through everything as a majority of concepts where well over my head. Lee, however, does a fairly good job at explaining the ramp-up to string theory as well as the basics. He then comes in with thought out criticisms and a variety of solutions that the scientific community could utilize. Overall, it is a great read for anybody that wants to see what goes on within the physics community.

I absolutely loved this book, especially once I finished slogging through the string theory part. There were times where I found myself going 'wow'... and frustrated at my inability to repeat back what I was reading to my wife. Back 20 years ago, when I had just finished my Physics degree, I'd've probably understood it better and been better able to explain what I was reading.Nevertheless, I thoroughly enjoyed it.Now, I just need to find someone to talk about it with!

Picked this up at the public library because it looked interesting and its cover proposes to answer questions I've been wanting to answer for myself. Unfortunately, as is the case often with books on theoretical physics, after the first introductory chapters it became a serious slog. I had to use up all my renewals at the library and in the end did a quick scan of the intervening chapters and then read through the final chapter.

I took Physics courses in college back in the sixties. This book is mostly about the last 30 years specifically about String theory so many terms were unfamiliar to me. It would have helped if there was a glossary at the back of the book. A major theme of the author is that new ideas that break away from the String orthodoxy are being stifled by the scientific establishment. I think the Brian Greene books(Hidden Reality, Elegant Universe) were better for the lay person than this.

I have to admit, I love Lee Smolin. The greatest of the big scientists when being an author for the general audience as well as someone not afraid to engage with other kinds of thinking in analogy to illustrate his point. Also, as a postgraduate student, I found it useful just for the expose on the complacency of any department, where prestige and entrenchment can be the enemy to any legitimate inquiry.

Best quote in the book: "No strategy will do better in every possible landscape than simply moving around randomly."Awesome look at what's happening in the physics community as of several years ago. Mostly over my head, but Smolin does a great job of illustrating how the prospect of a great discovery can result in a rush to get there when nobody really knows where "there" is.Totally worth a read.

First rate popular science writing--Smolin makes theoretical physics accessible but also conveys the complexity, limitations, and unknowns of the theories he discusses. I've nursed an interest in theoretical physics & cosmology for some time but suspected that both fields were not scientifically healthy. Smolin confirms that physics really does have deep theoretical and sociological problems. Very interesting to me.

A surprisingly clear and readable history of modern physics by one of the world's most notable string theory 'haters'. OK - not so much a hater as a critic of what he describes as near-religious (yet experimentally unfounded) dogma among string adherents, and an advocate for taking a more open-minded approach to physics research and education.

I am really enjoying hearing about the down side to String Theory. I have read both of Brian Greene's books and am glad to have more perspective on this theory that is dominating modern Physics. Leo Smolin gives what appears to be an unbiased overview of modern Physics in a concise and appealing manor.

I find these topics (theoretical physics, string theory, quantum mechanics, etc) super fascinating, even if I often have trouble grasping all the details. I finished this book, and I'm proud of myself for doing so. I didn't understand all of it. It was really, really hard. But sometimes, even if you're reading something you don't fully understand, you still get the sense that it's benefiting you in some way, you know? It's been a while since I read something this dense purely for leisure reading. I think it was worth it.

Really appreciated the author's passion for the truth, even though he ultimately denies truth in his personal philosophy and worldview.It was an interesting book, especially for the insights into the physics community. It was perhaps a little longer in some areas, but considering his audience it makes sense.

Amazing book clearly outlining the problems of physics that we have been stuck in for the last 30 years(both mathematical and social). The most accessible book on physics I've read, clearly explains string theory in a way that makes sense. Shows its failures and discusses the need for alternatives.

This book is more or less finished after the intro. That's the main issue of it, he makes his point and then continues to make the exact same point over and over again.However, his point of the postmodernism of string theory is quite correct and needed to be made, as the string theorists were inundating the market with their books on how awesome and elegant string theory actually is.

Quite well written and decidedly non-academic, it's an engaging look at the history, progress and non-progress of the physics field in the 20th century. It's more a story of people and institutions than of mathematics and physics, and Smolin seemingly put a lot of effort to making the latter accessible.

Not just a critique of string theory; a critique of theoretical physics as it stands and of the way science is done. This book does give a good (if now somewhat outdated) introduction to the major concerns of string theory, but the true purpose of the book is in the last few chapters and Smolin's reports on what it is to be a theoretical physicist.

Honest look at how physics works these days.Edit: Looking briefly at the reviews, I see lots of people had trouble getting through the string theory part. I did too, and I'm a physicist. Just skip to the last few chapters where he talks about the power structures in the field--that is the meat of the book.

This was pretty great, for a number of reasons - I just wish Smolin had taken it a bit further. At its current length, he is unable to fully explore his thesis with examples, case studies and counterarguments. Still, a great book and a very thoughtful analysis on the history and culture of modern physics research.

Not for the laymen, as a reviewer stated I think, at all. Maybe I approached the book wrong or I'm dim but the author doesn't explain things very well for me at all. The author when explaining things would talk as if you already knew all the technical stuff to start with and would repeat it, pushing on further having never really explained it well to start with.

String theory is the stable theory when it comes to theoritical physics.It's gonna open the flood gates to a hole brand new branch of physics and gonna answer some eternal questions as time travel and parallel universies ... Would recommend it to anyone who is new to string theory and are also interested in understanding the history. Excellent, overall.
