I've been so obsessed with Brian Greene and String Theory-- this book isn't as well-written as Greene's and doesn't explain things as well, but the information about other theories is interesting and gives added dimension to my knowledge of modern physics.

The author puts it far more politely than this, but string theory has been on the pot for a very long time with nothing to show for it. I was wondering why the physics books I read in college 30 years ago all seemed perfectly contemporary.

I grew up reading about physics, its triumphs, and heroes, so it's very interesting to read about the state it's in now. It also made me step back and think about the state of science in my own research area, which I very much appreciate. Clear, well-written, intriguing, and thought-provoking.

This book helped me to iron out the rest of my career path as a theoretical physicist, and allowed me to see just how important my ideas may turn out to be. Good for anyone who wants to understand what science is all about as a social phenomenon.

Though I had a hard time getting through much of the actual physics, I got great insight into the tragedy of string theory. Come on, strings in a dimension we can't see? Sounds like someone just wants to make the math work.

last 1/3 of book is more about academic politics than science, not sure how engaging that would be for the general public, though I agree with his assessments. otherwise he makes a compelling case, I was disappointed to hear just how speculative string theory's basis is.

I've followed theoretical physics for years. For some reason String Theory left me feeling something was lacking. Now I finally understand what it is. I feel like Lee Smolin has caught me up on 20 years of physics that I missed - despite the fact of regularly reading books about it.

I need to get a degree in physics. I was enthralled by the ideas expressed so simply in this book. I long to study the math and truly understand what the author was summarizing. A fascinating read, so many questions to be answered and problems to be solved.

I'm a geek at heart, my friends know this. I've always loved the concepts of governing rules of nature, physics. This book examines how little we have learned in the last 30 years and why and how the string theory of the universe hurts good scientific process.

Interesting review by physicist who dissents from current string theory enthusiasm. Pretty difficult to understand some of his arguments and conclusions, because a layman must take a lot of his technical statements on faith.

4.5 stars. I really enjoyed this thought-provoking, personal view of the state of theoretical physics. It re-ignited my interest in fundamental physics and made me think about my own choices and values.

A thought-provoking analysis of the nature of string theory (and, more generally, the academic system itself), and the damaging effect its supremacy is having on foundational thinking in modern physics.

Very interesting look at modern physics and why its progress has essentially been stalled for fifty years - lots of new hypotheses, but no breakthroughs. It also deals with the problems of physics education at the post-graduate level, and how the establishment blocks radical thinking.

Smolin certainly shows his own biases but the book is both an excellent look at the problems with String Theory and why the physics community's obsession with the theory is endangering the field of theoretical physics.

The first book on physics & string theory I've read that delves into the world of science academia and the career pressures of following mainstream physics (& the perils of trailblazing). Interesting insight into a world that the layman seldom considers. Well done Prof Smolin..!

Smolin doesn't exactly sweep the floor with string theory, but he shows clearly what is wrong with it and why it may be a dead end. Now, I would love to see what string theorists thought of The Trouble With Physics and what they have to say for themselves.

Interesting survey of physics and how the author considers the failing of science in favor of a trendy and elegant theory. There's a bit of selling his theories and defending his understanding of String Theory, but it is good nonetheless.

Disliked this book. Smug—a strongly negative tone without much goodwill. While there are technical merits in the arguments, they are overwhelmed by the lack of discussion towards substantive positive, forward-looking theory.

This is an important book for anyone concerned about the present state of science and progress. It clearly shows the whys, hows and whos of string theory's cultlike strangle-hold on modern day physics and reveals the sociological genesis of the problem.

I'm really interested in this topic, but I just don't have the stamina for long-winded and complex nonfiction. I mean, I finished the book and I checked out another book on a similar topic so who knows what I'm doing.

A critique of string theory as abandoning the scientific method. Mainly because there seems to be no available experimetal test to verify it. But, I would add that these experiments, or lack thereof, are not in principle not testable, but only the means are lacking to actually perform them.

Excellent critical book. A remarkable honest assessment of the state of theoretical physics by an honest first rank theoretical physicist. Points out all the issues with current theories, which most physicist rather not talk about!
